newsitem.title: GERMANY: Dollar gained due to strong U.S economy - Bundesbank.
newsitem.headline: Dollar gained due to strong U.S economy - Bundesbank.

text.p: The marked recovery in the U.S. dollar in recent months is essentially the result of the strength of the U.S. economy, the Bundesbank said on Wednesday.

In its 1996 annual report, which went to press when the dollar was at 1.73 marks, the central bank said: "This (strengthening process) primarily reflects the robust economic development in the United States which is taking place in an essentially tension-free environment."

"In addition to this, this trend also demonstrates that the structural burdens of the United States...are no longer the focus for international investors in view of the urgent need for budget consolidation in Germany and Europe," it added.
It cited the U.S. current account deficit and lack of domestic savings as structural burdens on the world's largest economy.

Turning to Europe, the Bundesbank noted that currency developments in relation to the mark last year had generally been calm, adding however that 1995's over-appreciation of the mark against European currencies had now fully receded.
Noting the clear recovery in sterling and the lira in recent months, the Bundesbank said this had helped to correct the "temporary distortions in international competitiveness".
